sentences: On 15 January 1520, the Czech Kingdom of Bohemia began <<||>> coins from silver mined locally in Joachimsthal and <<||>> on reverse with the Czech lion. The coins were <<||>> Joachimsthaler, which became <<||>> in common usage to thaler or taler. This name <<||>> into other languages: Czech tolar, Italian tallero, Polish talar, <<||>> – via Dutch – into English as dollar. Spanish pesos – having the same weight and shape – <<||>> as Spanish dollars. By the mid-18th century, the lion dollar had been replaced by Spanish dollar, the famous 'pieces of eight', which were <<||>> widely in the Spanish colonies in the <<||>> and in the Philippines. By the time of the American Revolution, Spanish dollars gained <<||>> because they backed paper money <<||>> by the individual colonies and the Continental Congress. <<||>> in the Thirteen Colonies, Spanish dollars were even legal tender in one colony, Virginia. Silver was mostly removed from U.S. <<||>> by 1965 and the dollar became a free-floating fiat currency without a <<||>> backing defined in terms of real gold or silver. The US Mint continues to make silver $1-denomination coins, but these are not intended for <<||>>. Via wikipedia.org
